raw_text:
Radcliffe enjoys winning comeback
 
 Paula Radcliffe made a triumphant return to competitive running with victory in the New York Marathon.
 
 The Briton, running for the first time since dropping out of the Olympic marathon and 10,000m, held off Kenyan Susan Chepkemei in a thrilling finish. The pair were locked together for the last few miles before Radcliffe finally sprinted clear to win in two hours, 23 minutes and 10 seconds. "It's a good way to end the year," she said. "I'm ready for a good rest now." Radcliffe decided only recently to run in the race and many had doubted whether she had sufficiently recovered from her Olympic ordeal just 11 weeks ago. But the world record-holder was prominent at the head of the field for the whole race as her rivals slowly dropped off the pace. Just Chepkemei and Radcliffe were left in contention as the race came into the final few miles. The Kenyan put in several bursts of speed to throw off Radcliffe but the Briton managed to hang in. Both runners looked to be suffering as they reached the final mile in Central Park. But it was Radcliffe who managed to dredge up a final sprint to see off Chepkemei in the closest finish in the race's history and in the process make a huge step in erasing the disappointment she suffered in Athens.

Her win marks progress towards overcoming disappointment from the Athens Olympics.

<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Paula Radcliffe winning the New York Marathon. The user provided an example summary that kept all key points without extra information or explanations.

First, I'll read through the original text carefully to understand each part. She was returning after dropping out of the Olympics and 10,000m race. She won with a thrilling finish in 2 hours, 23 minutes, and 10 seconds. The runner-up was Susan Chepkemei. They were locked together for the last few miles.

She said it's a good way to end the year, ready to rest. Many doubted her recovery after just 11 weeks ago but still won. The record holder led the race all along, losing Chepkemei and Radcliffe in the final moments with Radcliffe sprinting to finish first despite both being low on energy.

I need to make sure I include all key points: her comeback, victory, the finish time, Susan's rival, the impact of her efforts despite recovery issues. Also, mention how she felt afterward about rest and the race history.

I should structure it concisely, probably in three main ideas separated by some transition words. Make sure to keep each sentence clear and avoid unnecessary details unless they're important for the summary.
</think>

Paula Radcliffe won the New York Marathon with a thrilling finish of 2 hours, 23 minutes, and 10 seconds after her drop-out from the Olympics and 10,000m race. Despite only recovering from her injuries two weeks ago, she became a reminder of her recovery strength. The pair were locked together for nearly the last mile until Radcliffe sprinted to secure victory. She expressed joy about ending the year with a strong performance, ready to rest. Many doubted her ability due to limited recovery time, but Radcliffe emerged as a solid performer, leading despite her low energy levels. Her win was a significant step toward erasing disappointment from the 2008 marathon and highlighted her resilience.
tinyllama:1.1b: Psychologically, Paula Radcliffe was ready for a good rest after missing out on the Olympic marathon and 10,000m. She decided to run in the New York Marathon just a few weeks ago, but many doubts had been raised regarding her recovery from the Olympic games due to injury. However, in the thrilling finish of the race, Radcliffe made an impressive comeback by outsprinting Kenyan Susan Chepkemei after a tight battle for the lead. The world record-holder was prominent at the head of the field as both runners slowly descended into contentiousness, with Chepkemei putting up a spirited effort but failing to overhaul Radcliffe in the final mile. Despite suffering from injury, Radcliffe managed to outsprint her rival and emerge victorious. This marks a huge step for the Briton as she looks to make a comeback after missing out on the Olympics.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Radcliffe made a triumphant comeback in the prestigious New York Marathon, defeating Kenyan runner Susan Chepkemei in a thrilling two-hour, 23-minute, 10-second finish. Paula Radcliffe's victory in her first marathon since 2016 came off as an inspiring end to the year for the British runner, who had doubted whether she was ready to race after a challenging Olympic experience.

The 34-year-old, who held the world record for women's marathons until being ousted in Athens, faced many doubters who questioned her recovery from the Olympics where she suffered from heatstroke and dehydration while running 26.2 miles (42.1 km) at the 2016 Games. Despite these setbacks, Radcliffe remained focused on her goal of breaking the 2:20 marathon barrier at the New York race.

As Radcliffe and Chepkemei entered Central Park for the first time, both runners were determined to outrun their rivals. However, with only one mile left in the race, Radcliffe was suddenly joined by her competitor. The pair locked horns throughout the final miles as they sprinted against the clock. Ultimately, it was Radcliffe who prevailed, crossing the finish line in just 2:23:10 minutes, one second ahead of Chepkemei.

After completing her marathon, Radcliffe took a deep breath and acknowledged her victory before addressing the crowd. "I'm ready for a good rest now," she declared. The thrilling finish demonstrated not only the resilience of Radcliffe but also the strength and determination that come with overcoming adversity. Paula Radcliffe's return to competitive running after a long hiatus represents not only an incredible feat but also a testament to the human spirit and her unwavering commitment to achieve great things.

Despite doubters, Radcliffe held off Kenyan runner Susan Chepkemei in a thrilling finish that lasted two hours, 23 minutes, and 10 seconds.

After withdrawing from the Olympic marathon and 10,000m due to injury, she returned with a resounding victory over Kenyan Susan Chepkemei in two hours, 23 minutes, and 10 seconds. Despite doubts about her readiness following the Olympic ordeal (only a few weeks prior), Radcliffe dominated the race from the start, maintaining her position as the only competitor left when they entered Central Park. In the final miles, Chepkemei attempted to outpace Radcliffe but couldn't match her determination. Radcliffe demonstrated a powerful sprint to secure the win in one of the closest finishes in marathon history. This triumph significantly aids her recovery from the disappointing Olympic experience.
